title: 112_hr6530
content: The Act may be cited as the "Global Free Internet Act of 2012". The Global Free Internet Act of 2012 emphasizes the importance of a single, open, global Internet for the free flow of information and products across borders. Policies should encourage the use of international technology standards and prioritize the security and privacy of Internet users. The Global Free Internet Act of 2012 aims to promote investment in Internet-related innovation, prevent restrictions on the free flow of information, and support trade in Internet-related goods and services. Some governments and international bodies are considering policies that go against the goal of a free and open Internet by mandating unique technology standards. The Global Free Internet Act of 2012 aims to prevent restrictions on the free flow of information and support trade in Internet-related goods and services. Some governments are considering discriminatory policies regarding technology standards and Internet communications. The Global Free Internet Act of 2012 aims to prevent discrimination against Internet-based services and content from other countries, restrict individual privacy and freedom, and impede Internet-related goods and services from other countries. These actions threaten the interests of the United States by facilitating foreign governments' attempts to control Internet use. The Global Free Internet Act of 2012 aims to prevent foreign governments from restricting the free flow of information on the Internet, promoting national Internets that compromise the Internet's functionality, and harming US workers and businesses. The Global Free Internet Act of 2012 aims to prevent foreign governments from restricting the free flow of information on the Internet, protecting open communication, assembly, and commerce. This helps avoid putting foreign competitors at an advantage and risking the utility of the Internet for individuals. The Global Free Internet Act of 2012 establishes a Task Force on the Global Internet to prevent foreign governments from restricting the free flow of information online. The Global Free Internet Act of 2012 establishes a Task Force on the Global Internet within the executive branch, hosted by the Department of Commerce. The Task Force consists of four individuals with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties, selected by the President, who are not government employees. The Task Force on the Global Internet is comprised of individuals nominated by the public and appointed by the President through the President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology. They serve renewable terms not exceeding 3 years. Additionally, the leaders of the majority and minority parties in the Senate each appoint a United States person with substantial Internet expertise. The Task Force on the Global Internet includes individuals appointed by the President and leaders of the House of Representatives with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties for renewable terms not exceeding 3 years. The Task Force on the Global Internet includes appointed individuals with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties, along with leaders from various Federal departments and agencies as determined by the President. Federal agencies may detail personnel or services to the Task Force upon request. The Task Force on the Global Internet may receive personnel or services from relevant Federal departments to assist in its functions, which include developing strategies in response to government policies that impact international trade in Internet-related goods and services. The Task Force on the Global Internet aims to develop strategies to address government policies that affect international trade in Internet-related goods and services. This includes consulting with civil society groups and coordinating federal departments to implement these strategies effectively. The Task Force on the Global Internet will prepare a report and action plan, hold public hearings, solicit comments, and appoint a civilian member to lead and serve as a point of contact for the Task Force's activities. The Task Force on the Global Internet will prepare a report and action plan to be presented to the President and Congress. The Task Force will annually transmit a report and action plan to the President and Congress identifying acts, policies, or practices that deny fair market access. The Task Force will identify acts, policies, or practices that unjustifiably burden or restrict discourse or trade in Internet-related goods, services, and content, diverge from international standards, or threaten the interests of the United States in technical operation and security. The Task Force will identify measures impacting global Internet communications, assess their trade-distorting effects on US commerce and free expression, prioritize concerns, outline a response strategy for Federal agencies, and report on actions taken. The Task Force will provide information on actions taken in response to measures impacting global Internet communications, including required actions under section 5. Reports may include a classified annex if deemed necessary, and public participation will be sought through notice in the Federal Register. The Task Force will engage the public by publishing a notice in the Federal Register, holding public hearings, and establishing a website for comments. It will also consult with relevant government departments, agencies, and civil society. The Task Force will consult civil society groups and consider information from various sources, including reports and petitions submitted to the Trade Representative. The Task Force will publish the report and action plan in the Federal Register, excluding information from subsection (b). SEC. 5. SECTION 301 INVESTIGATION AND POTENTIAL SANCTIONS. The United States Trade Representative must initiate an investigation, make determinations, and take actions under sections 301 through 304 of the Trade Act of 1974 within 30 days of each annual report and action plan submission. This is in response to priority concerns regarding acts, policies, or practices of foreign governments or international bodies, including restrictions on the sale of products in the United States. SEC. 6. REVIEW AND INVESTIGATION BY FEDERAL TRADE COMMISSION AND DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE. The Federal Trade Commission and the Attorney General review and investigate acts, policies, or practices to determine if they violate antitrust laws. The term "antitrust laws" is defined in accordance with the Clayton Act. The term "antitrust laws" is defined in accordance with the Clayton Act, including section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act for unfair competition. SEC. 7. REPORT TO CONGRESS ON INTERNATIONAL TRADE AGREEMENTS. The Task Force will submit a report to Congress and the President within 2 years of the enactment of this Act. The report will assess existing trade agreements in promoting international trade in Internet-related goods, services, and content, encouraging global technology standards, protecting Internet security, and facilitating the free flow of information. The Task Force will submit a report to Congress and the President within 2 years of the enactment of this Act, recommending modifications or new agreements to advance objectives such as promoting international trade in Internet-related goods, protecting Internet security, and facilitating the free flow of information. Congress believes future trade agreements should include these goals. The Task Force will submit a report to Congress and the President within 2 years of the enactment of this Act, recommending modifications or new agreements to advance objectives such as promoting international trade in Internet-related goods, protecting Internet security, and facilitating the free flow of information. The report may contain a classified annex if deemed appropriate, and public participation is encouraged through notices, public hearings, and a dedicated website for timely information. The Task Force publishes information on its activities, allows public comments, consults with federal departments, shares information with civil society groups, and considers input from various sources. The Task Force will publish the report and action plan in the Federal Register, excluding certain information, as required by law. SEC. 8. STANDARDS-RELATED TRAINING. The Task Force will work with various entities, including government agencies and private sector organizations, to provide training to government officials and standard-setting bodies on best practices. This includes collaboration with international and domestic standards bodies, as outlined in the annual report and action plan. The Task Force will establish a process for receiving input from businesses, organizations, experts, and interested parties regarding its functions.
